newsitem.title: USA: Exxon big gasoline buyer on cat cracker problems.
newsitem.headline: Exxon big gasoline buyer on cat cracker problems.

text.p: Exxon Corp was a large and visible buyer of gasoline on Wednesday as the bulk of its catalytic cracking capacity was temporarily taken out of action, traders said.
Gasoline futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange shot up as the rumours of a problem at one of the cat crackers at its Baytown, Texas plant surfaced on Wednesday morning.
The September contract traded as high as 66.40 cents and closed at 66.00 cents a gallon, largely driven by Exxon's aggressive buying and the talk of the unit's problems.
The company confirmed late Wednesday that the unit was taken out of service after an "operational problem," though it wouldn't comment how long it would be down.
Exxon said its 110,000 barrels per day (bpd) Number 3 cat-cracker was down. The plant, with 411,000 bpd crude distillation capacity, has a total of 190,000 bpd of cat-cracking capability.
"Everyone is trying to guess how long it will be down," said a petroleum products trader for a major oil company.

An Exxon source familiar with the plant's operations said earlier on Wednesday that the unit was still "limping along" as the problem was assessed. He said a short downtime of a day or so was expected, though it was impossible to determine until the problem in the unit was evaluated.
"Exxon had bought about half-a-million barrels (of M1 grade) gasoline by 10.30 this morning," said a trader of U.S. Gulf gasoline.

He said that was about five days cover for Exxon and the company bought some more later, indicating that the cat-cracker was expected to be down for a week or so, typical turnaround time for a routine cat-cracker problem.
The gain in the futures and the half-cent gain in the premium put Gulf gasoline about a total of three cents a gallon higher on the day, traders said.
